H0.text: who was ptolemy and what did he do. Mathematician

H1.text: who was ptolemy and what did he do. Geographer

H2.text: who was ptolemy and what did he do. Cartographer

H3.text: who was ptolemy and what did he do. Astronomer

A4.text: Ptolemy's Almagest (originally Ancient Greek: Μαθηματικὴ Σύνταξις, romanized: Mathēmatikē Syntaxis, lit. 'Mathematical Systematic Treatise') is the only surviving comprehensive ancient treatise on astronomy.

A5.text: Ptolemy's Geography is a handbook on how to draw maps using geographical coordinates for parts of the Roman world known at the time.

A6.text: Ptolemy introduced a third device called the equant to create models for the other planets.

A7.text: Newton accused Ptolemy of systematically inventing data or doctoring the data of earlier astronomers.

A8.text: Ptolemy's system with epicycles and equant predicted celestial motions to within a maximum error of 10 degrees, considerably better than without the equant.

A9.text: Ptolemy's geocentric model was the predominant description of the cosmos in many European ancient civilizations.
